awd_titl_txt: Super Resolution THz Imaging of Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently invented super-resolution microscopes are having a large impact on the fields of chemistry, biology, and materials science, due to these microscopes providing previously unheard-of images of objects with dimensions approaching that of molecules. However, important chemical and electrical features of conducting and semiconducting nanomaterials cannot be visualized with existing microscopes, because of energy limitations associated with the light used. With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, and partial co-funding from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program in the Division of Materials Research of the National Science Foundation, Professor Hartland and his group at the University of Notre Dame are developing a new super-resolution microscope for recording images of materials through a novel approach that takes advantage of low-energy light in the terahertz region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The smallest sized feature the terahertz microscope can resolve is a few hundred nanometers, which is 100 to 1000 times better than previously possible. The newly unleashed power of the terahertz microscope is being used by Professor Hartland and graduate and undergraduate students to study materials that hold promise for more efficient solar cells and nanomaterials that may one day be used in ultra-sensitive chemical detection systems. It is anticipated that the new terahertz microscope will be adopted by researchers who study biologicals, superconductors, and integrated circuit devices, and ways to identify trace amounts of chemicals, such as residues from explosives. Efforts go beyond training of students at the university level, with a major focus being participation of high school students and teachers recruited from the Elkhart Community Schools, a local school district with students who come from highly diverse socioeconomic backgrounds. Sustained impact of the Elkhart School collaboration is being achieved by the high school teachers receiving graduate credits for their summer research activities. This program leads to teacher participants being able to teach Indiana University dual-enrollment courses, thereby broadening the educational opportunities provided by the Elkhart Community Schools.

Terahertz spectroscopy is widely used to examine semiconductors and plastics; however, currently existing terahertz microscopes have very low spatial resolution due to the diffraction limit. In a traditional terahertz microscope, the minimum feature size that can be resolved is determined by the wavelength of the impinging light divided by two, which is approximately 50 micrometers in the terahertz region. The unique approach taken by the Hartland group is based on a tightly focused visible probe beam that monitors absorption of a terahertz pump beam through the photothermal effect. The resolution in these experiments is dictated by the visible probe beam, and, as a result, is several hundred nanometers rather than tens of micrometers. The photothermal terahertz microscope is being used to examine photo-conductivity and the terahertz spectroscopy of thin films and individual nanostructures. These experiments are providing new information about the spatial distribution and motion of photo-excited charge carriers in the different structures, and the decay pathways for the charge carriers. This information is important for developing materials for photo-voltaic solar cells. Terahertz spectroscopy experiments are also being performed on the low frequency resonances of nanomaterials, which is generating new information about how these materials interact with their environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop a method for imaging materials with low frequency terahertz (THz) light based on photothermal microscopy.  These measurements were not successful, presumably because THz excitation only causes very small changes in the sample temperature due to the low absorption cross-sections of materials in the THz spectral region and the low energy of the THz sources.  The work in the project was redirected to understanding how heat dissipation affects the spatial resolution and detection limits in photothermal imaging experiments, using regular visible light lasers sources for excitation.  Experiments were performed on two different samples, both of which absorb green light: 50 nm diameter gold nanoparticles and micron-sized dye-doped polymer beads.  The measurements were performed in different environments, and with different experimental timescales (which were controlled by modulating the pump laser at different frequencies).  The measurements were corroborated with finite element simulations of heat diffusion in the different systems.

There were several significant Intellectual Merit outcomes from the project.  First, for gold nanoparticles only small changes in the spatial extent of the signal with timescale were observed, and that the features in the images were much smaller than the thermal diffusion length.  Heat transfer simulations show that the lack of sensitivity to timescale arises because the nanoparticles rapidly reach a steady-state condition, where heating from optical excitation is balanced by energy dissipation into the environment.  In this case the temperature profile around the particle is independent of the thermal diffusion length.  The steady-state condition is reached for modulation frequencies around 100 kHz for gold nanoparticles in the normal environments used for photothermal measurements.  Second, for experiments with polymer beads, reflected/transmitted light images recorded with a coherent source show intricate ring patterns that arise from a combination of diffraction effects and internal reflections within the bead. These patterns also appear in the photothermal images of the beads. The features in photothermal images arise from changes in the optical properties of the system induced by pump laser heating. For the polymer beads this includes changes in the size and refractive index of the bead from thermal expansion, and changes in the refractive index and density of the environment due to heat transfer from the beads.  When the beads are imaged in air the change in the refractive index of the environment is very small, so that the diffraction rings external to the bead do not appear in the photothermal images (the diffraction effects are essentially the same with and without pump laser excitation and therefore cancel out).  However, when the beads are imaged in an organic medium the change in refractive index of the medium causes a change in the diffraction pattern from the bead surface.  This gives rise to a strong ring pattern in the photothermal images external to the bead. Because of this effect, the beads appear larger than their physical dimensions in photothermal images in an organic medium.  The ring patterns can be eliminated by using an incoherent probe, although this significantly reduces the magnitude of the photothermal signal due to the much larger spot size of the probe at the sample. The photothermal images for the beads also show a significant dependence on the pump laser modulation frequency. This is because the heat transfer time is relatively slow for micron-sized beads, and on the order of the timescale of the experiments. 

The primary Broader Impacts of the project have been in student training.  Work on the project has directly contributed to the training of two graduate students (one of which has graduated and is now working in industry), two undergraduates and six high school students (four women and one under-represented minority).  The high school students were recruited from two local schools, four performed research as paid interns over the summer session (supported by NSF funds), and two performed research during the regular academic year.  The main scientific Broader Impact from this work is the observation that micron-sized polymer beads can appear larger than their physical size in photothermal images recorded in condensed phase media. This is significant for researchers who use photothermal measurements to characterize materials, such as microplastics in the environment.
